Do you think, Ronald, that there is support for the kind of educational policies of the Obama administration that will help make a difference?
I think that support can be generated.
I think right now people don't really understand what they're being asked to buy into.
I think that there are some things that need to be modified about the No Child Left Behind legislation, such as rewarding schools more effectively for progress.
I think there is a lot that we can do to help school and district leaders to understand better how to help teachers to be more effective in the classroom.
I think that Feds can be effective as a convener to help spread good ideas across states in this.
And so, I think the vision of what we actually intend to do differently in education has yet to be really spelled out and publicly shared.
And I think once that vision is shared and people develop a sense that it will make a difference, I would expect there to be quite of bit of support for funding it.
Well, Jane, Ronald mentioned No Child Left Behind, which we were going to mention as well, a program, of course, implemented by the former president.

Do you think that No Child Left Behind, as a policy under the Bush administration, has positioned the new president and putting him in a better or worse position to try to implement the kind of reform in education that will close this achievement gap?
Well, you know, people disagree about this, but I actually feel like No Child Left Behind was a step in the right direction in that it shone a bright light on achievement gaps.
It said to school districts, you can no longer report aggregate statistics; you have to report results separately for black children, white children, Latino children, for separate groups.
It didn't fund improvements; it didn't impose standard - you know, consistent testing systems.
There were lots of flaws in No Child Left Behind.
But the one thing it did do was a shine a bright light on achievement gaps and, you know, heighten the focus on accountability, which was the direction that the states were going, you know, anyway.
So, I think it was a useful step in the right direction, and - yes.

You know, I would just add, I mean, I do a fair amount of work with school districts, and I've sat in the number of meetings in school districts where people were thinking hard about ways to help students do better in ways that they would not have been doing if not for No Child Left Behind.
There was one meeting, one of the math department chairs said, well, my guys have been here a long time.
I just don't think how we're going to do any of this stuff any differently.
We just - you know, been there done that.
And the assistant superintendent said, look, somebody from the state going to be sitting in my office a week from now asking me what we are doing, and I've got to have an answer.
And so, if you're not going to do this, what are you going to do?
And the department chair, oh, well, OK, and you just gave me another reason to - maybe we will.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, that's one of the positive aspects of it, but in terms of the Obama administration, there is going to be a need for time, is there not, in order to make an effective change?
There would be - you know, but they're not starting some scratch in terms of thinking it through.
I mean, people have been thinking for the last several years about how they were going to advise the new administration to refine No Child Left Behind.
Now, they're going to have to sort through all those ideas, but there are quite a few ideas already on the table about ways to fix the ways that we measure progress and so on.

So, we have a place at the moment where we can measure the achievement gap between white and black and others, and at the end of the term of the president, we'll be able to measure again and see whether or not there's been any significant success.
